content.description: Surmount a cheater block stack to reach the lowest pockets in a bizarre swath of dark varnish riddled with small pockets. Boulder steep moves with terrible feet for a couple of moves until the angle lessens and the pockets get larger. Clip a bolt (nice to stick-clip, but full-length stick-clip needed), and shuffle right on a ledge to the upper, left-facing corner. Some tricky moves with tips lead to the cool hueco-ed midsection, and a stiff crack finish. A good pitch, but marred with some Schnebly silt and guano.
content.location: Just right of a fairly obvious, trodden "patio" at the base of the wall, which is the best hangout/staging area up here. Look for a bolt at roughly 12' and a very distinct pocket patch in dark varnish. The upper corner has an obvious black streak on the right wall.

content.description: Stretch high off the ground into a tips lock, undercling a roof and right-facing flake into a corner change with thin gear to a ledge. Softer rock leads up the corner, stem right on a jagged flake, clip a bolt and ride a rail back left into the very thin corner with some truly fortuitous holds that prove that Sedona wants us to climb! Finish up the very clean corner, which widens quickly from sub-tips to hands.
content.protection: 1 bolt   (1X) gray C3, purple C3   (2X) .1   (3X) .2   (2x) red C3, .3, .4, .5    (1X) .75, #2, #3   Clip-and-lower anchors.
content.location: Currently the right-most route on the wall. Look for a bolt at about 1/2 height, above a ledge. Look at the picture.

content.description: Start up some so so rock into the finger corner past a bolt on the left in a stem box into the steep thin hand to hand crack. Anchor just under the roof.
content.location: Middle of the wall. Look for a right facing corner under a small roof.

content.description: This might be one of the most beautiful pitches in Sedona.Climb up past a high bolt into the super thin offset crack. Sustained difficulties that slightly relent near the top as the pump builds.
content.protection: A whole herd of micro cams with a 000, 2x 00C3, 4x 0C3, 3x 1C3, 2x .3 to .4, 1x #1 and a solid head game will see you to the top.
content.location: Left side of the wall, the gorgous thin seam.

content.description: A cool stembox with fingers in the right-facing corner to a fistcrack bulge, offwidth/squeeze with good face features leads to a final fistcrack bulge to a large ledge and anchors.  A good fat option, with varied climbing and water-worn rock. Needless to say, in a different genre from the rest of the wall, but worthy if you want to hike a couple big cams out here.
content.protection: (1X) .3, .4, #1, #2, #3, #4, #5, #6   Chains (very thin gauge, bring some leaver biners to assist with pulls)
content.location: Currently the furthest left route on the wall. Roughly 100' left of the Magazine. A right-facing corner/stembox marks the start. A large Juniper sits just left of the route.

climbs.name: Chief of Beef
climbs.fa: FA Snyder, Harrison   FFA P1 Lor Sabourin

content.description: This dihedral is as hard as it is beautiful!P1  “5.12+“    From the nice ledge, lurch up into the sustained .2 crack on amazing stone with some face holds. Eventually the crack opens slightly and the climbing moderates before a easy bit to the anchor.  Finger size dependent but hard for eveyone over the age of 8.  First ascentionist Lor Sabourin compared it to the route Machete in Indian Creek.P2  5.11+    Plug up the finger corner past a wide pod into a steep off fingers section. Reminiscent of quality Wingate. Anchor on the right before things get ugly.
content.location: Left side of the wall. Starts on a mini perch off the ground. Impossible to miss.

content.description: A small collection of quality pitches on the sheer wall behind Beef Lord Spire. Wall is shady until about 3pm, but the dihedrals hold shade a little longer.
